messages.content:
You are a professional academic reference prediction expert. Your task is to predict the most likely references for a given academic paper based on its title, abstract, and retrieved relevant papers.

RETRIEVER INTERFACE:
- Input: paper title + abstract
- Output: {top_r} retrieved papers with title and abstract
- Format: List of dictionaries with 'title' and 'abstract' fields

REQUIREMENTS:
1. Analyze the paper's title and abstract to understand its research area and focus
2. Consider the retrieved papers as potential references (when available)
3. Generate a list of predicted reference titles that would be most relevant and likely to be cited
4. Provide reasoning for each prediction to prevent hallucination
5. Output format: JSON object with "titles" array and "reasoning" string
6. Generate exactly 51 most relevant reference titles (this should be at least 40 to cover all evaluation metrics)
7. Ensure titles are realistic and appropriate for the research area
8. Consider citation patterns in the field
9. CRITICAL: Each title must be unique - never repeat the same title multiple times

EXAMPLE:
Input:
Title: "Question Type Classification Methods Comparison"
Abstract: "The paper presents a comparative study of state-of-the-art approaches for question classification task: Logistic Regression, Convolutional Neural Networks (CNN), Long Short-Term Memory Network (LSTM) and Quasi-Recurrent Neural Networks (QRNN). All models use pre-trained GLoVe word embeddings and trained on human-labeled data. The best accuracy is achieved using CNN model with five convolutional layers and various kernel sizes stacked in parallel, followed by one fully connected layer. The model reached 90.7% accuracy on TREC 10 test set."

Retrieved papers ({top_r}):
1. Title: Convolutional Neural Networks for Sentence Classification
   Abstract: We report on a series of experiments with convolutional neural networks trained on top of pre-trained word vectors for sentence-level classification tasks.

2. Title: Glove: Global vectors for word representation
   Abstract: We present a new global log-bilinear regression model that combines the advantages of the two major model families in the literature.

Output:
{
  "titles": [
    "Convolutional Neural Networks for Sentence Classification",
    "Glove: Global vectors for word representation",
    "Quasi-Recurrent Neural Networks",
    "A Comparative Study of Neural Network Models for Sentence Classification",
    "Deep lstm based feature mapping for query classification"
  ],
  "reasoning": "Based on the paper's focus on question classification using neural networks, I predict these references because: 1) CNN paper is directly relevant to the convolutional approach used; 2) GloVe embeddings are mentioned as pre-trained features; 3) QRNN is one of the compared methods; 4) Comparative study papers are common in this field; 5) LSTM-based query classification is closely related to question classification. Additional references cover related neural network architectures, NLP applications, deep learning methodologies, optimization techniques, and advanced neural network methods that would be relevant for this research area."
}

Return JSON object only.

Paper Title: Predicting Motion Plans for Articulating Everyday Objects

Paper Abstract: Abstract Mobile manipulation tasks such as opening a door, pulling open a drawer, or lifting a toilet lid require constrained motion of the end-effector under environmental and task constraints. This, coupled with partial information in novel environments, makes it challenging to employ classical motion planning approaches at test time. Our key insight is to cast it as a learning problem to leverage past experience of solving similar planning problems to directly predict motion plans for mobile manipulation tasks in novel situations at test time. To enable this, we develop a simulator, ArtObjSim, that simulates articulated objects placed in real scenes. We then introduce SeqIK+Œ∏0subscriptùúÉ0\theta_{0}, a fast and flexible representation for motion plans. Finally, we learn models that use SeqIK+Œ∏0subscriptùúÉ0\theta_{0} to quickly predict motion plans for articulating novel objects at test time. Experimental evaluation shows improved speed and accuracy at generating motion plans than pure search-based methods and pure learning methods.

{retrieved_text}

Generate exactly 51 most likely reference titles for this paper. Focus on papers that are directly related to the research topic, provide foundational background, present similar methodologies, or address related problems.

CRITICAL: Each title must appear exactly once. Do not repeat any title.

IMPORTANT: You must respond with ONLY valid JSON in this exact format:
{
    "titles": [
        "Reference Title 1",
        "Reference Title 2",
        "Reference Title 3",
        "Reference Title 4",
        "Reference Title 51"
    ],
    "reasoning": "Explain why you chose these specific references based on the paper's title, abstract, and retrieved papers. This helps prevent hallucination and ensures relevance."
}

Do not include any text before or after the JSON. Do not include authors, venues, or years - only the paper titles. The reasoning field is required to explain your prediction logic.

{
    "titles": [
        "Learning to generalize kinematic models to novel objects",
        "A framework for door localization and door opening using a robotic wheelchair for people living with mobility impairments",
        "Detecting and modeling doors with mobile robots",
        "Obeying Constraints During Motion Planning, pages 1‚Äì32",
        "Task space regions: A framework for pose-constrained manipulation planning",
        "Whole-body motion planning for manipulation of articulated objects",
        "End-to-end object detection with transformers",
        "Planning for autonomous door opening with a mobile manipulator",
        "Manipulathor: A framework for visual object manipulation",
        "Real-time motion planning of legged robots: A model predictive control approach",
        "Threedworld: A platform for interactive multi-modal physical simulation",
        "Mask r-cnn",
        "Deep residual learning for image recognition",
        "Learning kinematic feasibility for mobile manipulation through deep reinforcement learning",
        "Learning sampling distributions for robot motion planning",
        "Learned critical probabilistic roadmaps for robotic motion planning",
        "Behaviors for robust door opening and doorway traversal with a force-sensing mobile manipulator",
        "Screwnet: Category-independent articulation model estimation from depth images using screw theory",
        "An adaptive control approach for opening doors and drawers under uncertainties",
        "Sampling-based methods for motion planning with constraints",
        "Exploring implicit spaces for constrained sampling-based planning",
        "Learning to open new doors",
        "AI2-THOR: An Interactive 3D Environment for Visual AI",
        "RRT-connect: An efficient approach to single-query path planning",
        "The hungarian method for the assignment problem",
        "Hrl4in: Hierarchical reinforcement learning for interactive navigation with mobile manipulators",
        "Category-level articulated object pose estimation",
        "Modern robotics",
        "Autonomous door opening and plugging in with a personal robot",
        "Articulated object interaction in unknown scenes with whole-body mobile manipulation",
        "Where2act: From pixels to actions for articulated 3d objects",
        "PartNet: A large-scale benchmark for fine-grained and hierarchical part-level 3D object understanding",
        "An experiment on opening-door-behavior by an autonomous mobile robot with a manipulator",
        "A simple strategy for opening an unknown door",
        "Perceptive model predictive control for continuous mobile manipulation",
        "High-level control of a mobile manipulator for door opening",
        "Habitat-matterport 3d dataset (HM3D): 1000 large-scale 3d environments for embodied AI",
        "A generalized framework for opening doors and drawers in kitchen environments",
        "Laser-based perception for door and handle identification",
        "igibson 1.0: a simulation environment for interactive tasks in large realistic scenes",
        "A unified mpc framework for whole-body dynamic locomotion and manipulation",
        "Learning obstacle representations for neural motion planning",
        "The Open Motion Planning Library",
        "Habitat 2.0: Training home assistants to rearrange their habitat",
        "Robot placement based on reachability inversion",
        "Normalized object coordinate space for category-level 6d object pose and size estimation",
        "Shape2motion: Joint analysis of motion parts and attributes from 3d shapes",
        "VAT-Mart: Learning visual action trajectory proposals for manipulating 3d articulated objects",
        "Relmogen: Leveraging motion generation in reinforcement learning for mobile manipulation",
        "Sapien: A simulated part-based interactive environment",
        "Visual identification of articulated object parts"
    ],
    "reasoning": "Selected these 51 references because they represent foundational work and recent advances in Predicting Motion Plans for Articulating Everyday Objects, providing essential background knowledge and methodological foundations relevant to this research."
}
